Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Environmental Justice and the Ethics of Science and Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to determine which types of air monitoring technologies and what kinds of scientific collaboration work best, the PI will compare monitoring projects with contrasting configurations of technology and collaboration. The PI will create and teach an annual science and engineering ethics course during which students will spend a week in a fenceline community learning from residents and other expert-activists about local environmental hazards and the technologies that produce them.


The project will create bridges between engineering professional communities and the public through exchange of expertise. The community collaborations she proposes will simultaneously broaden pathways for non-engineer citizens to actively and substantively participate in engineering projects and broaden the education of engineers to understand the community contexts and environmental justice implications of design decisions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to understand how people living next to oil refineries use data from ambient air monitors. In particular, refinery-adjacent communities often claim that the government and companies have certain obligations to protect them from pollution. This project asked how monitoring data are used to support or strengthen those claims.

One important outcome of the project has been Air Watch Bay Area, a website and app that better enables communities next to Northern California oil refineries to access fenceline monitoring data. In addition to viewing data, users can contribute their own observations and experiences, to put quantitative data in context. Air Watch Bay Area makes a contribution to information infrastructure and is one of the broader impacts of the project.

A second key outcome is a transformed understanding of the function served by community involvement in monitoring and other scientific endeavors. Community-led monitoring is often framed as "citizen science" and judged by the standards of established regulatory or academic science. This research shows that this common framing underestimates the import of community-led monitoring. Community monitoring practitioners have been engaged in "epistemic innovation"; that is, they do not aim simply to replicate the standards of science, but to extend the available methods and the phenomena that can be measured. Further, the success of community-led monitoring lies not primarily in whether monitoring data can be used to demonstrate that residents are being harmed by pollution. Instead, it is successful to the extent that it helps to repair damaged moral relations between communities--who often feel they are treated as expendable--and polluters, government, and the public. The concept of epistemic innovation and the idea that community-led monitoring has a reparative quality transform how scholars look at public engagement with science. They are central to this project's intellectual merit.

A final outcome of the project is the development of an undergraduate engineering ethics course. Entitled "Innovation and Social Justice," the course introduces students to social science models of how technology can transform society, and to political theories that help us define what constitutes a "better" or "more just" world. Students practice applying these concepts to innovation for a particular social issue. They walk away with a more robust understanding of their social responsibilities as STEM professionals and how to fulfil them. Among the broader impacts of the project is the effect of Innovation and Social Justice on students' intellectual growth and professional development.
